As maple leaves flutter and fall.
Evening bells ring from mountain temples as daylight fades.
At Yuliang Crossing, the ferry bustles with noise.
People follow sandy paths toward riverside villages.
I too board a boat, returning to Lumen.
Moonlight over Lumen illuminates mist - veiled trees.
Suddenly arriving at Pang Gong's secluded retreat.
Rock gates and pine paths lie in endless silence.
Only the recluse comes and goes in the night.
Before Huile Peak, the sand resembles snow.
Beneath Surrender City, the moon appears as frost.
From somewhere unknown, a reed pipe's song drifts by,
All night long, soldiers gaze toward their homeland's sky.
You ask when I’ll return, yet no date is set.
Night rain in Ba Shan swells autumn pools.
When shall we trim the candle by the west window together?
And reminisce about this night of rain in Ba Shan.
The deeper night's moon shines on half the houses.
The Dipper spans horizontal, Southern Dipper tilts.
Tonight, I especially sense the warmth of spring air.
Insect songs newly penetrate the green window screen.
Beyond the emerald railings, embroidered curtains hang low.
A crimson screen depicts broken branches in artful flow.
Eight - foot dragon - whisker mat with brocade square spread.
Cool autumn reigns, yet winter's chill lies ahead.
I deeply understand Song Yu's sorrow in autumn's decay, His graceful elegance remains my teacher to this day.
Gazing through millennia, tears freely flow, Though eras differ, desolation we both know.
His riverside home stands void of verse's trace, Could cloud - rain terraces be dreams' embrace?
Most poignant how Chu palaces turned to dust, Where boatmen point, their doubts still linger just.
Peaks and valleys converge towards Jingmen's gate,
Where still stands the village that bore Zhaojun, the Bright Consort's fate.
She ventured from Purple Palace into northern deserts' embrace,
Leaving but her verdant tomb beneath twilight's glow to face.
Through portraits glimpsed the spring breeze face so fair,
Yet jade pendants return in moonlit soul, bare.
A thousand years her pipa sings in barbarian tongue,
Resentment's thread through time in every note is strung.
The Shu lord spied on Wu through Three Gorges' might, His final year saw fall in Yong'an's twilight.
Jade banners linger in mountain's hollow core, While vanished palace merges with temple's floor.
Ancient shrine's cedars host waterfowl's domain, As elders tread through seasonal rites' terrain.
Zhuge's shrine stands near where royal rites convene, Sovereign and minister shared worship's sacred scene.
Zhuge's fame shines throughout the cosmos.
His solemn statue embodies noble grace.
Three kingdoms' strife through strategies he wove.
A timeless feather soaring skies above.
Peer to Yi and Lü in wisdom's light.
Outshining Xiao and Cao in command's might.
Han's fortune faded beyond recall.
His will unyielding, consumed by duty's thrall.
In the northeast, amidst the dust and turmoil,
Drifting through the vast expanse between heaven and earth in the southwest.
The towers of the Three Gorges drown in sun and moon.
The garments of Five Streams mingle with clouded peaks.
Barbarians serving lords prove faithless in the end.
The poet, in decline, still wanders, unable to return.
Yu Xin’s life was bleakest of all.
Yet his twilight verses shook the river passes.
The loving mother's threads in hand, her wandering son's clothes they mend.
Stitch by stitch before his parting, fear his return delayed in waiting.
Who says the tender grass's core, could repay the spring sun's glowing lore?
The old fisherman lodges by west cliffs at night.
At dawn draws clear Xiang water, burns Chu bamboo.
Mist disperses, sun rises, no soul in sight.
An oar's creak turns mountains and waters emerald.
Looking back at sky's edge midriver flowing down,
On cliffs, carefree clouds chase each other freely.
Human affairs ebb and flow, past and present interweave.
Rivers and mountains preserve renowned sites, we ascend again as our forebears did.
As waters recede, Yuliang Shoal lies bare; in cold skies, Mengze's depths appear profound.
Lord Yang's stele inscriptions remain, reading them brings tears that soak my lapel.

title: 玉台体十二首 十一
author: 权德舆

sentence.content: Last night my sash came loose.
This morning a spider flies.
Do not discard your cosmetics,
Could it be that my lord will return?
The fair maiden rolls up the beaded curtain.
She sits deep in thought, her moth - eyebrows knit in a frown.
Only the wet traces of tears are seen,
but who knows the one her heart resents?
Amidst the flowers, a jug of wine; I drink alone, no one close to share.
I raise my cup to the bright moon, facing my shadow, we become three.
The moon knows not the taste of wine; my shadow merely follows my form.
For now, I'll keep the moon and shadow; let's revel while spring remains.
I sing, the moon lingers; I dance, shadows scatter.
Awake, we share delight; drunk, we part ways in night.
Bound in passionless joy, we'll meet beyond the distant Milky Way.
Tonight's moon over Fuzhou,
In her chamber she gazes alone.
Afar I pity our children,
Too young to yearn for Chang'an.
Fragrant mists dampen her cloud - like hair,
Cold jade arms gleam in pure light.
When shall we lean by the gauze curtain,
Our tear - stains dried in shared moonlight?
Garrison drums halt travelers' tread, a lone goose's cry on autumn frontier.
From tonight, the dew turns frosty white, the moon shines brightest over home.
My brothers scattered far and wide, no home to seek news of life or death.
Letters I send never reach them, how much more while war still rages on.
Old friends parted by rivers and seas,
Countless times severed by mountain passes.
Sudden meeting seems but illusion,
In mutual grief we ask each other's age.
A lone lamp chills the rainy gloom,
Damp bamboos dim through floating mists.
Yet greater sorrow dawn will bring -
Farewell cups we cherish passing round.

title: 杂曲歌辞 长干曲四首 二
author: 崔颢

sentence.content: My home by the Nine - bend River's flow,
I come and go along its winding shore.
Though we're both natives of Changgan town,
Strangers since youth, our paths ne'er crossed before.

title: 杂曲歌辞 长相思三首 二
author: 李白

sentence.content: The daylight fades, flowers veiled in mist.
The moon shines pure, sorrow keeps me awake.
Zhao's zither rests on the phoenix pillar.
Shu's lute yearns to play mandarin duck strings.
This melody holds meaning, yet none to convey.
May spring winds carry it to Yanran's way.
I long for you beyond azure skies' array.
Eyes that once sparkled with rippling grace,
Now flow as fountains tracing tear's trace.
If doubt remains of my heart's breaking pain,
Gaze into the mirror upon your return.

title: 杂曲歌辞 长相思三首 一
author: 李白

sentence.content: Long yearning—in Changan.
Autumn crickets chirp by the gilded well rails.
Light frost chills the mat's hue.
A lone lamp dims, thoughts near despair.
Drawing curtains, I gaze at the moon and sigh in vain.
A flower - like beauty veiled by clouds.
Above, the vast azure heavens stretch;
Below, green waters surge with waves.
Endless skies, distant roads—my soul suffers in flight;
Even dreams cannot traverse the mountain passes' plight.
Long yearning—tearing heart and liver.

title: 杂曲歌辞 盖罗缝 一
author: 不详

sentence.content: The Qin moon shines on Han's strong passes, warriors march thousands of miles still far from home.
May Divine generals guard the Dragon Court, never let northern steeds cross Yin Mountain's fort.
Cherish not your golden clothes, but treasure your youthful prime.
Pluck the blossoms while they bloom, nor wait till branches bare you pine.
The sand before Mount Huile resembles snow,
the moonlight beyond Shouxiang City is like frost.
From where does the sound of the reed pipe drift, unseen?
All night long, the soldiers gaze toward their homes, hearts keen.

title: 杂曲歌辞 清平调 二
author: 李白

sentence.content: A crimson bloom, dew - kissed and fragrant.
Amidst the clouds and rain of Wu Mountain, hearts ache in vain.
Inquire of the Han Palace: who could compare?
Pitiable Fei Yan leans on her newfound grace.

title: 杂曲歌辞 清平调 三
author: 李白

sentence.content: The renowned flower and the beauty delight each other in mutual splendor.
The sovereign often gazes with a smiling countenance.
The gentle breeze dispels infinite sorrows of spring,
By Shenxiang Pavilion's northern railings we lean in quiet surrender.
The cassia spirit waxes as autumn dew glistens,
Gauzy silk gowns too thin, yet unchanged for the season,
The silvery zither's earnest notes linger through the night,
A trembling heart shuns the empty chamber's lonely light.
The morning rain of Weicheng dampens the light dust.
The inn's verdant willows gleam with spring's hue.
I urge you to drain one more cup of wine,
West beyond Yang Pass, no old friends remain.
Near Cold Food Festival rains make grasses lush.
Wheat sprouts sway, willows mirror the bank in breeze.
Long have I been homeward bound yet cannot return.
Cuckoo, cease your crying by my yearning ear.
You come from our hometown,
surely you know how things are there.
When you left by your gorgeous window,
has the winter plum blossomed yet?
I hear at Huanglong Garrison, years of unending strife.
The moon that lit her chamber now shines on the army's life.
A young wife's springtime longing, her husband's nightly pain.
Who'll lead us with banners and drums to break Dragon Town's chain?
Cicadas sing in the western land.
A captive's thoughts grow ever deeper.
How bear these dark-winged shadows,
Facing my white-haired lamentations?
Dew weighs their flight, progress hindered;
Winds drown their song, resonance smothered.
None believe in noble purity,
Who will voice this heart of mine?
At dawn I left White Emperor crowned with rainbow clouds;
To Jiangling I returned within a thousand - mile day.
Monkeys' endless wails echo from both riverbanks;
My skiff has flown past ten thousand somber peaks.
The leaves fall, the wild geese head south. The north wind chills the river.
My home lies by the Xiang River, remote beyond Chu's cloudy peaks.
Homesick tears dry in wanderer's eyes, a lone sail fades at sky's edge.
Lost at the ford, wanting to inquire - the evening sea spreads endlessly calm.
The long night brims with clear zither sounds.
West winds stir the emerald vines.
Fading fireflies bow to jade - like dew.
Early geese skim the Milky Way.
Tall trees at dawn remain dense and tall.
Distant hills gain clarity under clear skies.
A leaf falls in Huainan's embrace,
I feel age in the misty waves' trace.
In chaotic times we fled south together, now in peace I return north alone.
In foreign lands my hair turned white, returning home I greet green mountains.
Dawn moon passes ruined fortresses, under starry skies I lodge at old passes.
Chilled birds and withered grass everywhere mirror my sorrowful face.
So full of love, yet seemingly heartless all the time; At the farewell toast, I struggle to feign a smile.
The candle, with a heart, shares our parting sorrow, Shedding tears in our stead until the break of dawn.
Slim and graceful, just over thirteen.
Like early February's budding flowers on the branch.
Ten miles of spring breeze on Yangzhou's roads,
Rolling up beaded curtains, none compare to her.
I admire Master Meng, whose grace the world has known.
In youth rejecting honors, in white - haired years reclining by pines and clouds.
Drunk with moonlight, oft tasting divine wine; enchanted by blossoms, never serving lords.
How can I aspire to such lofty heights? Here I bow to your pure fragrance alone.
Moonlight traces the palace trees by the Forbidden Gate.
Enchanting eyes gaze solely at the swallows' nest.
Beside the lamplight's shadow, a jade hairpin tilts.
It parts the crimson flame to rescue the fluttering moth.
In February, orioles fly to Shanglin's bowers,
Spring veils Forbidden City in misty morning hours.
Changle Palace bells fade beyond blossoms fair.
Willows by Dragon Pond darken in rain's glower.
Sun's warmth cannot dispel my hopeless plight.
Yet still I cherish dawn's new celestial light.
Ten years of verse have brought no royal accord.
White - haired, I shame to face court's gemmed horde.
Life's meetings are rare as stars Shen and Shang.
What night is tonight, sharing this candlelight?
Youth's prime lasts but briefly; our temples now frost with gray.
Old friends half turned to ghosts, gasps scorch our burning core.
Who foresaw after twenty years, I'd climb your noble stairs?
Parted when you were single, now children stand in rows.
Cheerfully honoring father's friend, they ask my journey's path.
Before questions cease, they spread wine and dishes forth.
Night rain trims spring chives, fresh steam blends golden grain.
Host says meetings are rare, ten goblets raised in chain.
Ten cups bring no drunkenness, touched by your steadfast heart.
Tomorrow mountains divide us, life's affairs drift worlds apart.
The clear zither laments the long night.
Its strings quiver with the sorrow of wind and rain.
A lone lamp hears the Chu horn's mournful sound.
The waning moon descends over Zhang Terrace.
The fragrant grass has long since withered.
My old friend still has not arrived.
Letters to my homeland cannot be sent.
Autumn geese once again fly south.
Year after year at Jinhe and Yuguan Pass,
Each dawn brings whips and sword rings as we pass.
Spring snow returns to green graves where souls lie,
The Yellow River winds round Heishan for miles nigh.

title: 至德二载甫自京金光门出问道归凤翔乾元初从左拾遗移华州掾与亲故别因出此门有悲往事
author: 杜甫

sentence.content: In former days this path saw submission made, While western outskirts swarmed with barbarian horde.
To this day my shattered courage quakes, Where restless souls still haunt unsummoned.
Though recently returned to capital's embrace, This official transfer - was it truly the Emperor's will?
Talentless, I age with each passing day, Yet rein my steed to gaze at palace gates arrayed.
In middle age I grew fond of Tao, late dwelling by southern mountains' edge.
When moved, often wandered alone; these joys none but myself could gauge.
Walked till streams ended, sat watching clouds arise.
Met an old woodsman by chance, talked and laughed beyond time's gauge.
Taiyi nears the celestial capital.
Ranges connect to oceanic shores.
White clouds, gazing back, converge.
Blue mists, entering sight, vanish.
The central peak divides the realms
Shadows and light vary across valleys.
Seeking lodging where humans dwell
Across waters I hail the woodcutter.
The northern slopes of Zhongnan Mountain are majestic.
Snow-capped peaks float among the clouds.
The forest's edge glows with post - rain clarity.
Evening chill deepens in the city below.
In Qin land dwells Lady Luofu, picking mulberry leaves by green waters.
Her pale hands grace green branches, crimson attire shines in daylight.
Silkworms hunger, I must depart; five noble steeds, do not linger here.
A sheet of moonlight over Chang'an.
Ten thousand households' pounding of laundry.
Autumn winds that never cease,
Carrying thoughts of the Jade Pass evermore.
When will the barbarians be conquered,
So my love can end his distant campaign?

title: 自河南经乱关内阻饥兄弟离散各在一处因望月有感聊书所怀寄上浮梁大兄于潜七兄乌江十五兄兼示符离及下邽弟妹
author: 白居易

sentence.content: In times of hardship and famine, worldly affairs turn void.
Brothers wander as drifters, scattered east and west.
Fields lie desolate after war's devastation.
Kin wander displaced on endless roads.
Grieving shadows split into thousand - mile wild geese,
Uprooted, scattered like autumn's thistledown.
Gazing at the moon together, tears should fall -
One night's homesick hearts beat as five in unison.

title: 自夏口至鹦鹉洲夕望岳阳寄源中丞
author: 刘长卿

sentence.content: The isle's calm, without waves or mist's trace,
The wanderer's longing transcends time and space.
At Hankou's sunset, birds cross the slanting light,
Dongting's autumn waters merge with heaven's height.
Lonely town by cold ridge where horns resound,
Solitary watch by river where boats are bound.
Jia Yi petitioned, Han's fate to amend,
Banished to Changsha, loved beyond time's end.
